<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">sufficient market interest for us to continue in business.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If we are unable to develop markets for our K-Fuel products, our ability to generate revenues and profits may be negatively
impacted.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">If we are unable to construct and operate commercial K-Fuel production plants profitably, our ability to generate revenue from this process will be impaired.</font></i></b></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The commercial production of our K-Fuel product is relatively new and untested.&nbsp; Our future success depends on our ability to
successfully operate our existing commercial K-Fuel production plant at a profit, as well as to locate, develop and construct future commercial K-Fuel production plants at a profit.&nbsp; A number of different variables, risks and uncertainties affect our successful
construction of future K-Fuel production plants and our ability to operate such plants at a profit including:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">9</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the complex, lengthy and costly regulatory permit and approval process;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">local opposition to development of projects, which can increase cost and delay timelines;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">increases in construction costs such as contractors, workers and raw materials;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">high transportation costs and availability of transportation;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the possible future price increase of low-Btu coal, which could make the production of K-Fuel unprofitable; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">expenditures related to researching and investigating future K-Fuel production sites, which we may not be able to recover.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If we are unable to successfully address these risks, our results from operations and financial condition may be adversely
affected.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Competition from other companies in the clean coal and alternative fuel technology industries could adversely affect our market share.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Competition in the clean coal, alternative fuel and emission&#8209;reducing equipment industries could impact our ability to generate
revenue from our K-Fuel process.&nbsp; Many of these companies in the clean coal, alternative fuel technology and emission&#8209;reducing equipment industries have financial resources greater than ours.&nbsp; Due to these competitive advantages, our competition may
be able to offer products more competitively priced and more widely available than ours.&nbsp; These companies may also have the resources to create new technologies and products that could make our process and products obsolete.&nbsp; KFx's future revenues may
depend on our ability to address competition in these industries.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Deregulation in the United States power generating industry may result in increased competition, which could result in lower margins for our products.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We expect that deregulation in the United States power generating industry will result in utilities and other power generating
facilities placing a high emphasis on reducing costs in their operations.&nbsp; This situation may, in turn, result in increased competition from other producers of energy&#8209;efficient coal products, other clean fuel sources, and other products, services and
technologies designed to provide environmental and operating cost benefits similar to those which we believe are available from our K-Fuel products.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Regulation of the K-Fuel process and K-Fuel products may adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our products will be subject to federal, local, and foreign laws and regulations.&nbsp; In addition, as products are introduced into
the market commercially, governments may impose new regulations.&nbsp; Any regulation of our products, whether at the federal, state, local or foreign level, including any regulations relating to the development or sale of our products, may increase our costs and the
price of our products.&nbsp; If the cost of compliance with applicable laws and regulations increases past that forecasted, our ability to profitably market and sell K-Fuel products may be jeopardized.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Compliance with environmental laws and regulations may increase our costs and reduce our revenues.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our operations are subject to stringent and complex federal, state and local environmental laws and regulations.&nbsp; Failure to
comply with these laws and regulations may trigger a variety of administrative, civil and criminal enforcement measures, including the assessment of monetary penalties, the imposition of remedial requirements, and the issuance of orders enjoining future
operations.&nbsp; Certain environmental statutes impose strict, joint and several liabilities for costs required to clean up and restore sites where hazardous substances have been disposed or otherwise released.&nbsp; Moreover, it is not uncommon for neighboring
landowners and other third parties to file claims for personal injury and property damage allegedly caused by the release of substances or other waste products into the environment.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As we have acquired and may continue to acquire businesses with active or inactive coal mining operations, such as Landrica Development
Company and our pending purchase of Buckeye Industrial Mining Co., we have become and will become increasingly affected by federal, state and local laws and regulations affecting the coal mining industry, including laws and regulations pertaining to employee health
and safety, permitting and licensing requirements, air quality standards, water pollution, plant and wildlife protection, reclamation and restoration of mining properties after mining is completed, the discharge of materials into the environment, surface subsidence
from underground mining and the effects that mining has on groundwater quality and</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">10</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">availability.&nbsp; The costs, liabilities and requirements associated with these regulations can be costly and time&#8209;consuming, and could potentially affect our cash flow and profitability.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Future changes in the law may adversely affect our ability to sell our products and services.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; A significant factor in expanding the potential U.S. market for K-Fuel is the numerous federal and state environmental regulations,
which provide various air emission requirements for power generating facilities and industrial coal users.&nbsp; We believe that the use of clean&#8209;burning fuel technologies, like K-Fuel, helps utility companies comply with the air emission regulations and
limitations.&nbsp; We are unable to predict future regulatory changes and their impact on the demand for our products.&nbsp; While more stringent laws and regulations, including mercury emission standards, limits on sulfur dioxide emissions and nitrogen oxide
emissions, may increase demand for our products, such regulations may result in reduced coal use and reliance on alternative fuel sources.&nbsp; Similarly, amendments to the numerous federal and state environmental regulations that relax emission limitations would
have a material adverse effect on our prospects.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our inability to adequately protect and defend our proprietary process could harm our business, increase our costs and decrease the sales volume of our products and services.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our success depends upon our proprietary process.&nbsp; We rely on a combination of patent trademark and trade secret rights to
establish and protect our proprietary rights.&nbsp; We currently have a series of patents and patent applications on our K-Fuel process.&nbsp; However, competitors may successfully challenge the validity or scope of one or more of our patents, or any future
patents.&nbsp; These patents alone may not provide us with any significant competitive advantage.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Further, our current issued patent protection does not cover what we believe are certain unique aspects of our K-Fuel process, as it is
currently conducted.&nbsp; One of our pending United States patent applications include claims covering these unique aspects has been rejected.&nbsp; While this application currently stands rejected by the United States patent and trademark office as filed, they have
indicated that many of the claims presented in the application are most likely allowable.&nbsp; The application has been refiled to conform to the examiner&rsquo;s comments and we expect the patent to be granted as refiled.&nbsp; However, there can be no assurance
that we will be able to obtain patent protection in the United States or abroad to protect these or any other aspects of our intellectual property, or that, in the absence of any such patent protection, that the combination of additional methods that we currently
employ to maintain the confidentiality of our processes will adequately safeguard our proprietary processes and information.&nbsp; If our intellectual property is not adequately protected, this may have a material adverse impact on our financial condition, results of
operations and future prospects.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Third parties could copy or otherwise obtain and use our technology without authorization or develop similar technology
independently.&nbsp; The protection of our proprietary rights may be inadequate and our competitors could independently develop similar technology, duplicate our solutions, or design around any patents or other intellectual property rights we hold.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Any actions taken by us to enforce our patents or other property rights could result in significant expense as well as the diversion of
management time and resources.&nbsp; In addition, detecting infringement and misappropriation of patents or intellectual property can be difficult, and there can be no assurance that we would detect any infringement or misappropriation of our proprietary
rights.&nbsp; Even if we are able to detect infringement or misappropriation of our proprietary rights, litigation to enforce our rights could cause us to divert significant financial and human resources from our business operations, and may not ultimately be
successful.&nbsp; If we are required to divert significant resources and time to the enforcement of our proprietary rights, even if the enforcement is successful, our business could be materially adversely affected.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our success will depend on our ability to operate without infringing on or misappropriating the proprietary rights of others.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We may be sued for infringing or misappropriating the proprietary rights of others.&nbsp; Intellectual property litigation is costly,
and, even if we prevail, the cost of such litigation could adversely affect our business.&nbsp; In addition, litigation is time consuming and could divert management attention and resources away from our business.&nbsp; If we do not prevail in any litigation, we
could be required to stop the infringing activity and/or pay substantial damages.&nbsp; Under some circumstances, these damages could be triple the actual damages the patent holder incurs.&nbsp; If we have supplied infringing products to third parties for marketing
or licensed third parties to manufacture, use or market infringing products, we may be obligated to indemnify these third parties for any damages they may be required to pay to the patent holder and for any losses the third parties may sustain themselves as the
result of lost sales or damages paid to the patent holder.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If a third party holding rights under a patent successfully asserts an infringement claim with respect to any of our products or
processes, we may be prevented from manufacturing or marketing our infringing product in the country or countries covered by the patent we infringe, unless we can obtain a license from the patent holder.&nbsp; Any required license might not be available to us on
acceptable terms, or at all.&nbsp; Some licenses may be non-exclusive, and therefore, our competitors may have access to the same</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">11</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">technology licensed to us.&nbsp; If we fail to obtain a required license or are unable to design around a patent, we may be unable to market some of our anticipated products, which could have a material adverse effect on our
business.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We rely on key personnel and if we are unable to retain or attract qualified personnel, we may not be able to execute our business plan.</font></i></b></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our success is currently dependent on the performance of a small group of senior managers and key technical personnel.&nbsp; In
addition, our business strategy will require us to attract and retain a substantially greater number of qualified personnel.&nbsp; The inability to retain key managerial and technical personnel or attract and retain additional highly qualified managerial or technical
personnel in the future could harm our business or financial condition.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Any overseas development of our business is subject to international risks, which could adversely affect our ability to license, construct or operate profitable overseas plants.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We believe a portion of the growth opportunity for our business lies outside the United States.&nbsp; Doing business in foreign
countries may expose us to many risks that are not present in the U.S.&nbsp; We lack significant experience dealing with such risks, including political, military, privatization, technology piracy, currency exchange and repatriation risks, and higher credit risks
associated with customers.&nbsp; In addition, it may be more difficult for us to enforce legal obligations in foreign countries, and we may be at a disadvantage in any legal proceeding within the local jurisdiction.&nbsp; Local laws may also limit our ability to hold
a majority interest in the projects that we develop.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our acquisition activities may not be successful.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As part of our business strategy, we may make acquisitions of businesses and properties.&nbsp; However, suitable acquisition candidates
may not be available on terms and conditions we find acceptable.&nbsp; Further, acquisitions pose substantial risks to our financial condition and results of operations.&nbsp; In pursuing acquisitions, we compete with other companies, many of which have greater
financial and other resources to acquire attractive companies and properties.&nbsp; Even if future acquisitions are completed, the following are some of the risks associated with acquisitions:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the acquired businesses or properties may not produce revenues, earnings or cash flow at anticipated levels;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">we may be unable to integrate acquired businesses successfully and realize anticipated economic, operational and other benefits in a timely manner;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">acquisitions could disrupt our ongoing business, distract management, divert resources and make it difficult to maintain our current business standards, controls and procedures;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">we may finance future acquisitions by issuing common stock for some or all of the purchase price, which could dilute the ownership interests of our stockholders; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">we may incur additional debt related to future acquisitions.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Failure to maintain effective internal controls in accordance with Section&nbsp;404 of the Sarbanes&#8209;Oxley Act of 2002 could have a material adverse effect on the market's perception of our business and our ability
to raise capital.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have documented and tested our internal control procedures in order to satisfy the requirements of Section&nbsp;404 of the
Sarbanes&#8209;Oxley Act.&nbsp; The Sarbanes&#8209;Oxley Act requires annual management assessments of the effectiveness of our internal controls over financial reporting and a report by our independent auditors addressing these assessments.&nbsp; If we fail to
maintain the adequacy of our internal controls, as such standards are modified, supplemented, or amended from time to time, we may not be able to ensure that we can conclude on an ongoing basis that we have effective internal controls over financial reporting in
accordance with Section&nbsp;404 of the Sarbanes&#8209;Oxley Act.&nbsp; Further, this assessment maybe complicated by any acquisitions we may complete.&nbsp; While we continue to dedicate resources and management time to ensuring that we have effective controls over
financial reporting, failure to achieve and maintain an effective internal control environment could have a material adverse effect on the market's perception of our business and our ability to raise capital.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Risks Relating To Our Common Stock</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our stock price and trading volume may be volatile, which could result in substantial losses for our stockholders.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The equity trading markets may experience periods of volatility, which could result in highly variable and unpredictable pricing of
equity securities.&nbsp; The market price of our common stock could change in ways that may or may not be related to our</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">12</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">business, our industry or our operating performance and financial condition.&nbsp; In addition, the trading volume in our common stock may fluctuate and cause significant price variations to occur.&nbsp; For example, since the
beginning of the fourth quarter of 2004, our stock price has appreciated approximately 175%.&nbsp; Our current market price and valuation may not be sustainable.&nbsp; If the market price of our common stock declines significantly, you may be unable to resell your
common stock at or above its purchase price.&nbsp; We cannot assure you that the market price of our common stock will not fluctuate or decline significantly in the future.&nbsp; In addition, the stock markets in general can experience considerable price and volume
fluctuations.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Provisions in our articles of incorporation, bylaws and Delaware law may make it more difficult to effect a change in control, which could adversely affect the price of our common stock.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Provisions of our articles of incorporation, bylaws and Delaware law could make it more difficult for a third party to acquire us, even
if doing so would be beneficial to our stockholders. &nbsp; We may issue shares of preferred stock in the future without stockholder approval and upon such terms as our board of directors may determine.&nbsp; Our issuance of this preferred stock could have the effect
of making it more difficult for a third party to acquire, or of discouraging a third party from acquiring, a majority of our outstanding stock and potentially prevent the payment of a premium to stockholders in an acquisition.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our articles of incorporation and bylaws contain provisions that could delay, defer or prevent a change in control.&nbsp; These
provisions include:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">giving the board the exclusive right to fill all board vacancies;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">providing that special meetings of stockholders may be called by the president, chairman of the board or by the board, and shall be called by the president, chairman or secretary after receipt of a written request signed by
holders of at least 10% of the outstanding shares;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">a classified board of directors; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">permitting removal of directors only for cause and with a majority vote of the stockholders.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; These provisions also could discourage proxy contests and make it more difficult for you and other stockholders to elect directors and
take other corporate actions.&nbsp; As a result, these provisions could make it more difficult for a third party to acquire us, even if doing so would benefit our stockholders, and may limit the price that investors are willing to pay in the future for shares of our
common stock.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are also subject to provisions of the Delaware General Corporation Law that prohibit business combinations with persons owning 15%
or more of the voting shares of a corporation's outstanding stock for three years following the date that person became an interested stockholder, unless the combination is approved by the board of directors prior to the person owning 15% or more of the stock, after
which the business combination would be subject to special stockholder approval requirements.&nbsp; This provision could deprive our stockholders of an opportunity to receive a premium for their common stock as part of a sale of our company or may otherwise
discourage a potential acquirer from attempting to obtain control from us, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on the market price of our common stock.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">A substantial number of shares we have issued in exempt transactions are, or are being made, available for sale on the open market, and the resale of these securities might adversely affect our stock
price.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have on file with the SEC effective registration statements for a substantial number of shares for resale.&nbsp; The selling
stockholders under our effective registration statements will be permitted to sell their registered shares in the open market from time to time without advance notice to us or to the market and without limitations on volume.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The sale of a substantial number of shares of our common stock under our registration statements, or the anticipation of such sales,
could make it more difficult for us to sell equity or equity&#8209;related securities in the future at a time and at a price that we might otherwise wish to effect sales.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have not paid cash dividends on our common stock and do not anticipate paying any dividends on our common stock in the foreseeable future.</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We anticipate that we will retain all future earnings and other cash resources for the future operation and development of our
business.&nbsp; Accordingly, we do not intend to declare or pay any cash dividends on our common stock in the foreseeable future.&nbsp; Payment of any future dividends will be at the discretion of our board of directors after taking into account many factors,
including our operating results, financial conditions, current and anticipated cash needs and plans for expansion.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">13</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<h5><a name="i1b"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 1B.&nbsp; UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">None.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><a name="tx14120_2"></a><a name="i2"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;PROPERTIES</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We previously entered into a lease through May 2007 for office space to accommodate our headquarters, which is located in Denver,
Colorado.&nbsp; We consider our headquarters sufficient to meet our near-terms goals.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In May 2004, we purchased Landrica Development Company, or Landrica.&nbsp; Through Landrica, we own approximately 1,000 acres of land
located in Campbell County, Wyoming (near Gillette, Wyoming).&nbsp; Our demonstration facility and our 750,000-tons per year plant are both located at this site.&nbsp; The land also includes various coal processing equipment, certain industrial buildings, waste
injection wells, producing water wells, a coal-mining pit and a railroad spur.&nbsp; These assets occupy only a portion of the total acreage of the site.&nbsp; As a result, there is acreage available for expansion or use for other purposes, subject to certain
restrictions.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><a name="i3"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Except as provided below, we are not engaged in any material legal proceedings to which we or any of our subsidiaries are a
party.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; On April&nbsp;14, 2005, we were notified that we were named in a Demand for Arbitration by Ohio based Ultramax Corporation and
its affiliate, Decision Control Analysis Corporation (&ldquo;Ultramax&rdquo;).&nbsp; In April 2002, Ultramax granted a License Agreement (&ldquo;Agreement&rdquo;) to Pegasus Technologies, Ltd. (&ldquo;Pegasus&rdquo;) in which we owned a majority interest at the time,
for certain software which was to be used for the optimization of industrial and other processes, including processes used in the electric power generation industry.&nbsp; The Agreement provided for the payment of certain minimum royalties.&nbsp; KFx executed the
Agreement along with Pegasus.&nbsp; The Agreement provided that Pegasus and KFx were both licensees and were jointly and severally liable.&nbsp; While we were not aware of this dispute until receipt of the Demand for Arbitration, Pegasus has previously refused
Ultramax&rsquo;s claims for the payment of minimum royalties on the basis that the software did not perform as promised.&nbsp; Ultramax disagrees and claims that the terms of the Agreement have been breached.&nbsp; Ultramax is claiming damages of up to $4
million.&nbsp; On May 24, 2005, Pegasus and KFx entered into an agreement whereby Pegasus has agreed to &ldquo;indemnify and hold harmless KFx for any monetary award or other judgment received by Ultramax through the arbitration, including any attorney&rsquo;s fees
or costs awarded to Ultramax.&rdquo;&nbsp; Pegasus and KFx have retained counsel and continue to vigorously defend the arbitration, which is currently scheduled for hearing on April 3, 2006.&nbsp; At the present time, it is not possible to predict the outcome of this
arbitration.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><a name="i4"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; None.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
14</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>

</div>

<p align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PART II</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><a name="tx14120_5"></a><a name="i5"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MARKET FOR COMMON STOCK, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>

</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As of February 28, 2006, we had approximately 230 holders of record of our common stock.&nbsp; This does not include holdings in street
or nominee names.&nbsp; On February 28, 2006, the closing price of our common stock was $20.88 per share.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Dividend Policy</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have never paid cash dividends and do not anticipate paying dividends in the foreseeable future.&nbsp; We expect that we will retain
all available earnings generated by our operations for the development and growth of our business.&nbsp; Payment of any future dividends will be at the discretion of our board of directors after taking into account many factors, including our operating results,
financial conditions, current and anticipated cash needs and plans for expansion.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Recent Sales of Unregistered Securities</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In January 2005, we issued an aggregate of 19,305 shares of common stock, 200,000 warrants with an exercise price of $5.00 and 400,000
warrants with an exercise price of $8.52 to Venners &amp; Company, Ltd. and Public Relations of America, Inc. pursuant to previously executed consulting agreements.&nbsp; These securities were sold in private transactions pursuant to an exemption from registration
requirements of the Security Act of 1933, as amended under section 4(2).</font></p>

<p><a name="tx14120_6"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
15</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<h5><a name="i6"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SELECTED FINANCIAL DATA</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following selected consolidated financial data should be read in conjunction with, and are qualified by reference to, our
Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes thereto in Item 8 of this report and Management&rsquo;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations included in Item 7 of this report.&nbsp; The selected consolidated financial data for
each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2005 and the selected consolidated balance sheet data as of December 31, 2005 and 2004 are derived from, and qualified by reference to, our audited Consolidated Financial Statements, in Item 8 of this
report.&nbsp; The selected consolidated results of operations data related to 2002 and 2001 and selected consolidated balance sheet data related to 2003, 2002 and 2001, have been derived from audited financial statements not included in this report and have been
revised from prior filings for our discontinued operations unless otherwise noted.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

operation was $4.8 million as of December&nbsp;31, 2001.</font></p>

<h5><a name="i7"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MANAGEMENT&rsquo;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with, and are
qualified by reference to, our Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes thereto in Item 8 of this report and Selected Financial Data included in Item 6 of this report.&nbsp; Certain reclassifications have been made to prior year amounts to conform to
current year presentation.&nbsp; Certain statements set forth below under this caption constitute &ldquo;forward-looking statements&rdquo; within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform of 1995.&nbsp; Refer to the &ldquo;Cautions About Forward Looking
Statements&rdquo; preceding Item 1 of this report.&nbsp; Also, for a discussion of certain risk factors applicable to our business and operations see &ldquo;Risk Factors&rdquo; in Item 1A of this report.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Overview</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We offer combined energy, environmental and economic solutions to coal-fired power generating facilities and industrial coal users in
the United States and internationally.&nbsp; Our proprietary K-Fuel process uses heat and pressure to physically and chemically transform high moisture, low-Btu PRB coals, such as subbituminous coal and lignite, into a more energy efficient, lower&#8209;emission
fuel.&nbsp; A co-benefit of the K-Fuel process is the removal of significant amounts of impurities, including mercury, and the reduction of emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following discussion is focused on the recent events that we believe have the most significant impact on our business.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have substantially completed the construction of our 750,000-tons per year K-Fuel plant and mine project in Wyoming's PRB, which is our first commercial plant implementing the K-Fuel process;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We completed our first two production runs using feedstock coal with less than 8,000 Btus at the 750,000-tons per year plant.&nbsp; The initial production runs resulted in coal that was approximately 11,000 Btus, with a
moisture content of between 8% and 12%, meeting our desired specifications for K-Fuel product.&nbsp; Further, the initial product showed a reduction in mercury of approximately 70% from the feedstock coal;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We entered into a stock purchase agreement with Keller Group,&nbsp;Inc. to acquire its wholly owned subsidiary Buckeye Industrial Mining Co. Buckeye's primary business is to mine, process and sell coal to power generating
facilities and industrial users.&nbsp; The acquisition would provide us with established markets, infrastructure, blending facilities, coal supply, and operating cash flow;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In February 2006, we sold 7 million shares of common stock at a price to the public of $18.75&nbsp;per share pursuant to a follow-on common stock offering.&nbsp; On February 27, 2006, the underwriters exercised in full their
over allotment option, purchasing an additional 1.1 million shares of common stock.&nbsp; Including the over-allotment, the offering totaled 8.1 million shares of common stock at a price of $18.75, resulting in net proceeds of approximately $144.4 million after
deducting the underwriting discounts and commissions and estimated offering expenses.&nbsp; We plan to use the proceeds from this offering to fund the contemplated acquisition of Buckeye, new plant facility construction costs, the purchase of a coal-fired boiler and
general corporate purposes.&nbsp; If we are unable to close the acquisition of Buckeye, we intend to use the proceeds to further the development of our K-Fuel plants and for any acquisitions we may identify in the future;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have signed agreements to evaluate the potential of constructing and operating plants located in the PRB.&nbsp; We have also signed a memorandum of understanding with a coal producer to access their mine site location in
Louisiana to determine the viability of a K-Fuel plant at that location;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>

</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We strengthened our executive management team by adding an experienced operational Chief Executive Officer; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>

<tr>
<td valign="top">

</td>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We purchased MR&amp;E, a research engineering and project management firm focused on thermal process engineering, including upgrading and processing of clean coal.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our financial statements include all of our wholly owned subsidiaries, including MR&amp;E, acquired in March 2005 and Landrica,
acquired in May 2004; both are more fully discussed in Item 1 of this report.&nbsp; During 2003, as part of an exchange transaction with Kennecott, we transferred our ownership of Pegasus to Kennecott for the remaining interest in KFL that we did not own.&nbsp; As a
result of this exchange, we have accounted for Pegasus as a discontinued operation and have accordingly removed its effects from our results of continuing operations for 2003.&nbsp; KFL is now a wholly-owned subsidiary.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">17</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Historically, we reported results for our business in one segment.&nbsp; In December 2004, we entered into an agreement to license our
proprietary coal processing technology.&nbsp; Due to this licensing agreement we now operate our business in two segments, the licensing segment and the operating segment.&nbsp; The licensing segment represents&nbsp;revenue and costs related to the licensing of our
technology, which comprises of virtually all of our revenue in 2005 and 2004.&nbsp; The operating segment contains all other operations.&nbsp; As we operated our business in a single segment in prior years, our discussion is focused on our overall operations, rather
than by segment, unless otherwise indicated.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Significant Trends</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; For the last several years, our operations have been focused on developing our technology and the construction of the 750,000-tons per
year plant.&nbsp; As a result, we have limited revenues and most of our costs are related to general and administrative expenses.&nbsp; In the future, we plan to own and operate K-Fuel production facilities domestically, both wholly owned and through joint ventures,
as well as to license the K-Fuel technology to third parties, primarily internationally.&nbsp; As our operations expand, we expect our revenue and cost structure will also expand.&nbsp; The following discussion and analysis is focused on the events and trends that we
believe have the most significant impact on our business.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></h5>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Revenue Trends</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In the future we expect to generate revenue from the following sources:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">sales of K-Fuel from joint ventures and wholly owned production facilities;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">licensing of our technology, including license fees for constructing a plant and royalty fees for operating a plant; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">consulting services to parties who license our technology.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, to the extent that we execute on our vertical integration strategy and acquire companies that conform to our business
strategy, we anticipate revenues from those sources as well.&nbsp; For example, we have entered into a stock purchase agreement to acquire Buckeye, and if we complete this acquisition, we could begin recognizing revenue related to their business.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have granted certain rights and limited licenses for the use of certain K-Fuel technology, which may limit our revenue from
production of K-Fuel to the extent that the rights are exercised.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></b> Expense Trends</h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As we begin to operate our wholly owned and potential joint venture plants, we expect that our cost structure will change.&nbsp;
Currently, the majority of our costs are related to general and administrative efforts.&nbsp; As plants begin operations, we will incur additional expenses, the most significant of which are:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Feedstock;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">non-cash, share-based compensation;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">

</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">utilities; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">royalty costs, relating to fees we owe to parties who own certain rights that support our patents and proprietary technology, primarily the Koppelman estate.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We anticipate that accounting for non-cash, share-based compensation will add approximately $9 to $10&nbsp;million per year in the
foreseeable future to our expenses.&nbsp; In the event we should achieve certain performance goals, we would significantly accelerate recognition of these costs.&nbsp; Costs such as feedstock, payroll and utilities are variable costs that increase with the size and
the location of the plant and the year in which they are incurred.&nbsp; As a result, we cannot currently estimate what these costs will be until such time as a plant becomes operational.&nbsp; See further discussion of the royalty owed to the estate of Edward
Koppelman in Note 5 &ndash; Deferred Royalty Costs in Item 8 of this report.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Revenue</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Revenue for the year ended December 31, 2005, was $984,000.&nbsp; For the years ended December 31, 2004 and 2003, our revenues were
inconsequential to our business.&nbsp; The majority of the increase in 2005 was attributed to the recognition of revenue of $768,000 on the $7.5 million up-front licensing fee received in December 2004 and recorded in our licensing segment.&nbsp; To</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">18</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">date we have completed all of our contractual deliverables for the licensing fee and are waiting for Cook Inlet Coal LLC to provided specific site information before the next phase of revenue recognition can
commence.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

2003.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Employee-related costs primarily include salaries and wages, bonuses, benefits, and related benefits, as well as non-cash, share-based
employee compensation costs.&nbsp; Employee-related costs were $6.2 million, $2.2 million and $1.7 million for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; We recognized non-cash expense for equity compensation in the amount of $2.2 million,
$463,000 and $467,000 for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; The remaining increases in 2005 and 2004 were primarily related to an increase in salaries and related burdens as we hired more employees at our corporate and plant office
and from the acquisition of MR&amp;E in 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Professional fees include legal, audit and accounting, public relations and similar costs.&nbsp; Professional fees were $6.1 million,
$5.3 million and $4.6 million for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; We experienced fluctuations in professional fees due to the following:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2005 included $2.4 million of non-cash expense related to the issuance of stock to a consultant in exchange for services performed;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2004 included $2.2 million of consulting fees relating to assistance with regulatory issues, the majority of which is non-cash for the issuance of warrants and stock;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2003 included $1.1 million of legal fees related to a lawsuit settled in January 2004.&nbsp; In 2004, we negotiated a reduction in our legal costs, which we had previously accrued in 2003.&nbsp; This reduction of $521,000 was
applied to legal fees expensed in 2004.&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Travel and entertainment costs are primarily comprised of airfare, lodging and meals.&nbsp; Our travel and entertainment costs were
$719,000, $219,000 and $461,000 for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; The increase in 2005 was due to additional non-plant related employees and management traveling to the 750,000-tons per year plant site and increased
international travel related to visits to Lurgi South Africa&rsquo;s facilities and other business development opportunities.&nbsp; During 2003, there was significant travel as we evaluated different methods of improving our K-fuel product and process, primarily
related to the implementation of Lurgi South Africa&rsquo;s equipment.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Office expenses include rent, office supplies, phone, utilities, publications, and subscriptions.&nbsp; Office expense were $530,000,
$365,000 and $411,000 for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; The increase was due to increases in all aspects of office expense due to the expansion of our business and the increase in the number of employees.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Insurance primarily includes costs related to our commercial and liability insurance.&nbsp; Insurance expense were $478,000, $321,000
and $252,000 for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; Increases were attributed to an overall increase in general and commercial liability premiums for our 750,000-tons per year plant.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Other general and administrative is comprised of expenses that cannot be categorized elsewhere and include, among other costs, various
business and franchise taxes, repair and maintenance and board of director fees and expenses.&nbsp; Other general and administrative expenses were $6.2 million, $334,000 and $88,000 for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; In 2005, we
incurred $5.8 million of non-cash expense related to the issuance of warrants to Arch Coal, Inc.&nbsp; In</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">19</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2004, we recognized non-cash stock-based compensation for a member of the board of directors of $136,000 for the extension of the expiration date of his options.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mine and Plant Expenses</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mine expenses include costs associated with security, Mine Safety and Health Association regulatory compliance, property taxes, asset
retirement obligation accretion expense and other costs necessary to maintain an open-pit coal mine.&nbsp; Additionally, these expenses include payments associated with evaluating the potential for utilizing our coal mine to provide feedstock supply to our K-Fuel
plant such as: maintenance to the pit roads, coal testing, and other feasibility study costs.&nbsp; Plant expenses include pre-operating costs incurred to prepare our 750,000-tons per year plant for operations, such as: costs incurred to hire and train personnel for
the operation of our plant, establish health and safety plans, develop environmental compliance plans, define operating manual procedures and other administrative costs.&nbsp; Plant expenses also include administrative personnel, office supplies, utilities, vehicle
maintenance and other insignificant purchases.&nbsp; Mine and plant costs were $&shy;&shy;&shy;&shy;1.9 million and $154,000 for the years ended December 31, 2005 and 2004.&nbsp; There were no such expenses for the period ended December 31, 2003.&nbsp; We expect
these costs to increase once we begin commercial production at our 750,000-tons per year plant and coalmine.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>
