<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The pro forma amounts reflected above may not be representative of the effects on our reported net income or loss in future years
because the number of future shares to be issued is not known and assumptions used to determine fair value vary significantly.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Income taxes.</i></b>&nbsp; We follow the liability method of accounting for income taxes under which deferred tax assets and
liabilities are recognized for future tax consequences.&nbsp; A deferred tax asset or liability is computed for both the expected future impact of differences between the financial statement and tax basis of assets and liabilities and for the expected future tax
benefit to be derived from tax loss and tax credit carryforwards.&nbsp; Valuation allowances are established when necessary to reduce deferred tax assets to the amount expected to be realized, based upon an assessment of both negative and positive evidence, in future
tax returns.&nbsp; Tax rate changes are reflected in the period such changes are enacted.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Net loss per common share.</i></b>&nbsp; Basic net loss per common share is based on the weighted-average number of common shares
actually outstanding during each respective year.&nbsp; The calculation of diluted net earnings per common share adds the number of potential common shares outstanding to the weighted-average common shares actually outstanding, except for instances in which there is
a net loss.&nbsp; Our incremental potential common shares outstanding at December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 are 22.9 million, 19.4 million and 23.4 million, respectively and are comprised of stock options and restricted stock grants outstanding as described in Note 7
&ndash; Stock Option Plans and Employee Benefit Plans and warrants to purchase our common stock as described in Note 8 - Warrants.&nbsp; All potential common shares outstanding have been excluded from diluted net loss per common share because the impact of such
inclusion on a net loss would be anti-dilutive.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Comprehensive income.</i></b>&nbsp; Comprehensive income includes all changes in equity during a period from non-owner
sources.&nbsp; During each of the three years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, we had no transactions that were required to be reported as adjustments to determine comprehensive income.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-9</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><i>Recent Accounting Pronouncements</i></b>.&nbsp; In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB, issued&nbsp; SFAS No.&nbsp;123R,
&ldquo;Share-Based Payments,&rdquo; or SFAS 123R.&nbsp; SFAS 123R requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in financial statements based on the fair value of the equity or liability instruments issued.&nbsp; SFAS 123R
covers a wide range of share-based compensation arrangements including share options, restricted share plans, performance-based awards, share appreciation rights, and employee share purchase plans.&nbsp; Effective April 2005, the Securities and Exchange Commission
extended the implementation date to the beginning of a registrant&rsquo;s next fiscal year beginning after June&nbsp;15, 2005. &nbsp; As a result, we will not be required to implement SFAS 123R until the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006.&nbsp; We anticipate that
adoption will result in non-cash, stock-based compensation expense between $10 million to $12 million during 2006, based on the number of unvested stock options and restricted stock awards outstanding as of December 31, 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <a name="OLE_LINK1">In May&nbsp;2005, the FASB, as part of an effort to conform to international accounting standards, issued SFAS
No.&nbsp;154, &ldquo;Accounting Changes and Error Corrections,&rdquo; which is effective for us beginning on January&nbsp;1, 2006.&nbsp; SFAS No.&nbsp;154 requires that all voluntary changes in accounting principles be retrospectively applied to prior financial
statements as if that principle had always been used, unless it is impracticable to do so.&nbsp; When it is impracticable to calculate the effects on all prior periods, SFAS No.&nbsp;154 requires that the new principle be applied to the earliest period
practicable.&nbsp; The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;154 is not anticipated to have a material effect on our financial position or results of operations.</a></font></p>



<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(2)&nbsp;Acquisitions</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; MR&amp;E LLC, a research and engineering firm focused on thermal process engineering, including the upgrading and processing of clean
coal, was acquired due to its significant expertise in thermal process engineering.&nbsp; We acquired all of the outstanding membership interests effective March&nbsp;1, 2005 for cash of $656,000.&nbsp; Their operations have been included in our financial statements
as of the effective purchase date of March&nbsp;1, 2005.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Following is a summary of the estimated fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as of the effective date of the
acquisition (in thousands):</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-10</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The operating results, including revenue and net income for 2005, 2004 and 2003 were insignificant.&nbsp; Therefore, pro-forma results
as if the acquisition had occurred at the beginning of the respective period are not presented.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On May&nbsp;21, 2004, we acquired all of the outstanding stock of Landrica Development Company from Wyodak Development Corporation for
cash of $523,000 and assumption of an asset retirement obligation of $2.7 million.&nbsp; The results of Landrica have been included in the consolidated financial statements from the date of acquisition.&nbsp; Landrica owns a coalmine and related assets that include
land, buildings, coal handling equipment, a railroad loop and other pieces of equipment and property.&nbsp; See further discussion of our asset retirement obligation in Note 3 Construction In Progress and Property and Equipment</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Following is a summary of the estimated fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as of the date of the acquisition
(in thousands):</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Since Landrica was not operating the mine during 2004 or 2003 the operating results, including revenue and net income are
insignificant.&nbsp; Therefore, pro-forma results as if the acquisition had occurred at the beginning of the respective period are not presented.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In November 2003, we acquired all interests in KFL, not previously owned pursuant to the exchange agreement more fully disclosed in
Note 9 - Discontinued Pegasus Operations and Note Receivable.&nbsp; Prior to the date of the transaction, we owned 51% and Kennecott Energy Company owned 49% of the interests.&nbsp; As a result of this transaction, KFL is now consolidated within our financial
statements.&nbsp; Through the date of our acquisition we recognized a loss of $209,000 for our share of the expenses of KFL.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Construction in progress is comprised of costs associated with the construction and operation of our K-Fuel plant and KFx mine
project.&nbsp; These project costs include long-lived improvements to our mine located near our plant</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-11</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">site and a new train loadout silo being constructed to improve our unit-train loadout capacity.&nbsp; The 750,000-tons per year plant line item includes:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$7.6 million and $3.3 million of accrued costs as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top"></td>
<td valign="top"></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>

</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$726,000 and $671,000 of capitalized asset retirement cost as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Depreciation expense was $563,000, $268,000 and $111,000 in 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 2004, we impaired assets of $1.3 million related to certain site-specific and plant size-specific costs incurred associated with
evaluating three other locations, including Black Thunder, Coal Creek and Buckskin, for our 750,000-tons per year plant.&nbsp; Impairments during 2003 totaled $107,000, relating primarily to scrap metal.&nbsp; There were no such impairments during the year ended
December 31, 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On September&nbsp;28, 2005, we entered into an Option Agreement with Buckskin Mining Company, a subsidiary of Kiewit Mining Group, or
Kiewit.&nbsp; The Option Agreement gives us a license to conduct a site review, exploratory core drilling and geotechnical surveys for the purpose of determining the feasibility of construction of a 4 million tons per year K-Fuel plant to be located on or adjacent to
Kiewit&rsquo;s Buckskin mine in the Powder River Basin, in Wyoming.&nbsp; The option to construct the plant extends to January&nbsp;1, 2007 and the decision to proceed with the plant construction is at our sole discretion during the option period.&nbsp; In addition,
if the option is exercised, we will enter into a previously negotiated long-term coal supply agreement, a site sublease and facilities usage agreement.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On October 5, 2005, we entered into an agreement with Arch Coal Inc. that provides for us to have the right for immediate access to
certain land at Arch&rsquo;s Coal Creek Mine located in the Powder River Basin for the purpose of conducting exploratory core drilling and geotechnical surveys. &nbsp;Based upon the results of this testing, we will evaluate the feasibility of permitting, constructing
and operating an eight million tons per year K-Fuel plant at the Coal Creek Mine to beneficiate coal that is supplied from the Coal Creek Mine.&nbsp; See Note 6 - Stockholders Equity for further discussion relating to the Arch agreement</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></b> Asset Retirement Obligation</h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our asset retirement obligations relate to our acquisition of Landrica and the improvements we have made at the site on which our
750,000-tons per year plant is being constructed as well as the mine site and train loadout silo.&nbsp; The following table reconciles the change in the asset retirement obligation during the year.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<td nowrap height="17" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">3,558</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>

<tr height="3">
<td height="3" valign="top"></td>
<td height="3" valign="top"></td>
<td height="3" valign="bottom" bgcolor="black"></td>
<td nowrap height="3" valign="bottom" bgcolor="black"></td>
<td height="3" valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have allocated the asset retirement cost to the underlying assets based the fair value using an expected cash flow approach, in
which multiple cash flow scenarios that reflected the range of possible outcomes and a credit-adjusted risk-free rate were applied.&nbsp; The liability was then accreted over time by applying the interest method of</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-12</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">allocation at a rate we estimate to be 5.4%.&nbsp; We began depreciating the assets on a straight-line basis.&nbsp; The increase in our asset retirement obligation was related to the development of our 750,00-tons plant and as
a result will be amortized over the estimated useful life of the plant once it is placed into service.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(4)&nbsp;Patents</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Patents consisted of the following:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">

</td>

<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(in years)</font></p>
</td>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Patent amortization expense, including abandoned patents pending, was $210,000, $152,000 and $264,000 in 2005, 2004 and 2003,
respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Most of our early patents are near their expiration dates.&nbsp; Our later patents will not expire until 2018 through 2021.&nbsp; Our
current issued patent protection does not cover what we believe are certain unique aspects of our K-Fuel process, as it is currently conducted.&nbsp; One of our pending United States patent applications includes claims covering these unique aspects has been
rejected.&nbsp; While this application currently stands rejected by the United States patent and trademark office as filed, they have indicated that many of the claims presented in the application are most likely allowable.&nbsp; The application has been re-filed to
conform to the examiner&rsquo;s comments and we expect the patent to be granted as re-filed.&nbsp; If rejected we still have other approved patents that we believe are crucial to the K-Fuel process that do not expire until 2021.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(5)&nbsp;Deferred Royalty Costs</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Deferred royalty costs were comprised of deferred costs related to the issuance of license for K-Fuel and a one-time payment made to
Mr. Edward Koppelman, the inventor of the K-Fuel process.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The deferred royalty costs associated with the issuances of licenses for K-Fuel represent the licensing fees paid to the Koppelman
estate, described below.&nbsp; Such costs are amortized over the same period as the deferred revenue related to the underlying contracts.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 1996, we entered into a royalty amendment agreement with Mr. Koppelman, or subsequent to his death, the Koppelman estate, that
reduced the cap for payments by $500,000 to $75.2 million and set the royalty percentage at 25% of our worldwide licensing and royalty revenue, as defined in the agreement.&nbsp; In addition, Mr. Koppelman provided us an indemnification against potential claims made
by certain parties if we licensed the technology.&nbsp; We</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-13</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">paid Mr. Koppelman a total of $500,000 pursuant to the agreement as a prepayment.&nbsp; The $500,000 has no specified expiration date and recognition is solely dependent upon the issuance of licenses.&nbsp; As a result, the
payment has been reflected in deferred royalty costs in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.&nbsp; We are amortizing the $500,000 payment as license revenue is generated.<font color="black">&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005, there is $73.1 million remaining under the
cap.&nbsp;</font> Also, see discussion in Note 11 &ndash; Commitments and Contingent Liabilities &ndash; Royalties and Other Rights.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mr. Theodore Venners, our Chairman and Chief Technology Officer, or CTO, is entitled to 50% of net royalties to be paid to the
Koppelman estate.&nbsp; In December 2004, Mr. Venners entered into a waiver agreement with us, under which he agreed to assign his right to payments that became due to him from the estate in connection with the license arrangement entered into in 2004.&nbsp; Pursuant
to the waiver, Mr. Venners is obligated to remit any proceeds he may receive related to this license agreement to us.&nbsp; As we did not have the right to offset the amount owed to the estate against the amount we expect to receive from the estate, we accrued the
entire amount due to the Koppelman estate in Accrued Liabilities in our 2004 Consolidated Balance Sheets.&nbsp; In addition, we have recorded a Related Party Receivable in our 2004 Consolidated Balance Sheets representing the amount due back from the Koppelman
estate.&nbsp; In February 2005, we paid $1.9 million due to the estate and the estate remitted Mr. Venners&rsquo; portion directly back to us.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><a name="OLE_LINK6"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(6)&nbsp;Stockholders&rsquo; Equity</font></b></a></h5>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the fourth quarter of 2005, we sold 191,000 shares of our common stock to Arch for proceeds of $3 million, which were used for
general corporate purposes.&nbsp; The shares were sold in connection with the execution of two agreements with Arch, which (1) allow us to evaluate the potential of constructing and operating a plant at their Coal Creek mine site located in the PRB and (2) requires
us to issue warrants.&nbsp; We issued 2.5 million warrants to Arch to purchase our common stock.&nbsp; See further discussion of the warrants in Note 8 - Warrants and agreements in Note- 3 - Construction in Progress and Property and Equipment.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><a name="OLE_LINK7"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the second quarter of 2004, we sold 245,400 shares of common stock to Arch for gross proceeds of
approximately $2 million and incurred $5,000 in placement costs.&nbsp; We used these proceeds for general corporate purposes.&nbsp; On November 24, 2004, we sold 4 million shares of our common stock, in a private placement to a limited number of accredited investors,
at $12.00 per share, resulting in net proceeds of $45.4 million.&nbsp; We used $39.2 million of the proceeds for future plant and project development and $6.2 million for working capital needs.</font></a></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In two transactions in March 2003, we issued a total of 7.7 million shares of our common stock at a price of $2.50 per share and
warrants to purchase 1.5 million shares of our common stock, which resulted in cash proceeds to us of $19.4 million.&nbsp; See further discussion of the warrants in Note - 8 Warrants.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2002, we entered into a series of transactions with three investor groups whereby we issued a total of 6.8 million shares of our
common stock and 14.4 million warrants.&nbsp; The investors have certain rights pursuant to an investor rights agreement, including the right for one group to select two persons to serve on our Board of Directors.&nbsp; As a result, Richard Spencer, manager of
Westcliff Capital Management LLC, was added to our Board of Directors.&nbsp; This provision remains in force until the investors hold less than 400,000 shares of our common stock.&nbsp; During 2005, we renegotiated the investor rights agreement executed in connection
with the issuance of the shares in 2002 to provide us greater flexibility in constructing and operating plants.&nbsp; Subsequent to the renegotiation, we and the investors have the following rights:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">One investor group continues to have the right to select two persons to serve on our Board of Directors.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">All investors may develop or participate, with up to a 15% interest, in the greater of K-Fuel commercial projects with an annual output capacity of 50 million tons per year or six commercial plants.&nbsp; Such right will not
be in effect until we have plants in operation or have binding contracts to construct plants for which the aggregate designed or projected annual output is at least 25 million tons per year.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We can participate in projects developed by the investors, other than in India, up to a 50% interest.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The investors retain the right to develop in India as long as certain conditions are met.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The investors are obligated to pay certain royalty and license fees for these plants, if constructed.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-14</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The rights expire 20 years after the 25 million tons annual capacity threshold is reached or earlier, if the investors exercise their
rights to 50 million tons of annual capacity.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>



<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(7)&nbsp;Stock Option And Employee Benefit Plans</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Stock Option Plans</font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have five qualified stock option plans, under which 12.5 million shares are reserved and 5.2 million shares are available for grant
as of December 31, 2005.&nbsp; These plans are administered by the Compensation Committee of our Board of Directors, or the Committee, which has the authority to determine the specific terms of awards under these plans, including grant price, vesting and term,
subject to certain restrictions of the Internal Revenue Code regarding incentive stock options, or ISOs.&nbsp; From time to time, we have issued stock options related to various compensation and fee agreements with directors, employees and outside consultants that
were not issued pursuant to our five option plans.&nbsp; Future non-plan grants can only be made as inducement grants to new officers or employees, pursuant to American Stock Exchange rules, unless shareholder approval has been obtained.&nbsp; The five qualified
stock option plans and the non-plan awards are collectively referred to as &ldquo;the plans.&rdquo;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Generally, the plans provide for the award to our executive officers and other key employees, non-employee directors and consultants
and others of Non-Qualified Stock Options, or NSOs, ISOs, stock appreciation rights, or SARs, and restricted stock.&nbsp; Stock options granted under the plans generally vest 20 percent on each anniversary date until fully vested.&nbsp; Vesting of restricted stock
grants vary and may vest as early as on grant date and as late as on seventh anniversary of the grant date.&nbsp; The Committee can accelerate the vesting of an outstanding award at its sole discretion.&nbsp; Certain of the plans contain provisions requiring the
acceleration of vesting of all outstanding awards in the event of a change in control, as defined in those plans.&nbsp; Stock options granted under the plans generally expire not more than ten years from the date of grant.&nbsp; All but one of the five qualified
plans has been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.&nbsp; The non-plan awards are generally registered with other registration statements that we periodically file.&nbsp; All stock options granted during each of the three years ended December 31,
2005 were at exercise prices that were equal to or greater than the fair market value of our common stock on the date of grant.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following table summarizes our stock option activity, including both plan and non-plan options, for the three-year period ending
December&nbsp;31, 2005:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<td height="3" valign="bottom" bgcolor="black"></td>
<td height="3" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="3" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="3" valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-15</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Plan and non-plan stock options outstanding and exercisable as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 are summarized below:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have granted 2.1 million, 111,000 and 139,000 shares of restricted and non-restricted stock to our employees and directors for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003.&nbsp; We have granted 150,000, 5,000 and 137,000 shares of restricted stock to consultants for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003.&nbsp; As of December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, 2.1 million and
100,000 shares of restricted stock were unvested.&nbsp; All other grants are fully vested.&nbsp; During 2005, our former President and Chief Operating Officer forfeited 80,000 shares of restricted stock upon his termination.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have recognized $2.2 million, $463,000 and $467,000 in non-cash compensation expense related to our employees and directors for the
years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively, which is reflected in general and administrative expenses.&nbsp; We have recognized $2.4 million, $3.0 million and $224,000 in non-cash compensation expense related to non-employees for the years ended
December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively, which is reflected in general and administrative expenses.&nbsp; These expenses primarily related to the issuance and vesting of restricted stock awards.&nbsp; The more significant transactions and expenses are
described below.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In February 2005, we granted a total of 1 million options to our new President and Chief Operating Officer.&nbsp; All of the options
are considered inducement options as defined by the American Stock Exchange, are not issued pursuant to a plan and vest 20% per year beginning in January 2006.&nbsp; Additionally, in March 2005, the Committee approved the grant of 100,000 shares of restricted stock,
vesting 20% per year beginning January 2006.&nbsp; We recognized $330,000 of non-cash compensation expense related to the restricted stock during the year ended December 31, 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the fourth quarter of 2005, we granted 2 million shares of restricted stock to our new CEO, Executive Vice President of Finance
and Strategy and our CTO (our former CEO).&nbsp; The 1.4 million issued to the new CEO and Executive Vice President of Finance and Strategy were not issued pursuant to a plan because they are considered&nbsp; inducement awards.&nbsp; The 600,000 issued to our CTO
were granted from one of our plans.&nbsp; Full vesting of the stock will occur upon attainment of any of the following:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the average closing price of our common stock for the trading days within any 90 consecutive calendar day period equals or exceeds $45.05 per share;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">annual gross revenues increase to $1 billion;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">annual net operating cash flow increases to $250 million; or</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">change in control, as defined in the agreement occurs after the two-year anniversary of the agreement.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-16</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Further, partial vesting, as defined in the agreement, may occur if certain lesser targets are achieved.&nbsp; Unless sooner vested
pursuant to the incentive targets described above, the restricted stock shares will fully vest on the seventh anniversary of the date of the agreement so long as the individual is continually employed.&nbsp; Related to these awards, we recognized $679,000 of non-cash
expense during the year ended December 31, 2005.&nbsp; Pursuant to the employment agreements, we were required to transfer the 2 million shares to an escrow agent; such transfer occurred in February 2006.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the year ended December 31, 2005, we granted an additional 250,000 shares of restricted stock to our CTO that vest upon
achievement of certain operational criteria related to our 750,000-tons per year plant and will vest 20% on the achievement date and 20% annually thereafter on the anniversary date of the grant.&nbsp; We recorded $281,000 of non-cash expense related to this award
during the year ended December 31, 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the year ended December 31, 2005, we granted 140,000 shares of restricted stock to a consultant for services rendered.&nbsp; As
a result, we recorded $2.4 million of non-cash compensation during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In December 2004 and again in January 2005, we granted 86,000 and 100,000 options to a new officer and members of our Board,
respectively pursuant to a plan, which had not been approved by the shareholders.&nbsp; As stockholders was not approve this plan until June 2005, the measurement date was not fixed and as a result, we were required to record compensation expense reflecting the
excess of the fair value over the exercise price of the options granted.&nbsp; We recorded $43,000 and $95,000 of compensation expense for the years ended December 31, 2005 and 2004, respectively, which is reflected in general and administrative expenses.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In November 2004 and again in February 2005, the Committee voted to extend the exercise periods for vested options for a period of 90
days after the resignation of a director and our former President and Chief Operating Officer, respectively.&nbsp; As a result of these extensions, we recorded general and administrative expense of $136,000 in 2004 related to the extension of 40,000 options and
$906,000 in 2005 related to the extension of 120,000 options.&nbsp; The expense represents the difference between the fair value of the options on the date the extension was granted and the exercise price.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Employee Stock Purchase Plan</font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the third quarter of 2005, the Committee approved the establishment of an Employee Stock Purchase Plan, which is subject to
shareholder approval.&nbsp; If approved by our shareholders at the 2006 Annual Meeting, 100,000 shares of our common stock would be eligible for issuance to employees.&nbsp; Until June 30, 2006, employees may contribute to the plan, subject to certain maximum
contributions, and be eligible for a 15% discount from the lower of the market price on November&nbsp;1, 2005 or June&nbsp;30, 2006, the first purchase date pursuant to the plan.&nbsp; After June&nbsp;30, 2006, the employees would be eligible for monthly purchases at
the lower of the beginning or end of the month market price.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-17</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(8)&nbsp;Warrants</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Associated with various financing and other transactions and professional service agreements, we have issued transferable warrants to
purchase common stock, which generally immediately vest.&nbsp; The following table summarizes the outstanding warrant activity for years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004, and 2003:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="684">
<tr height="17">
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td colspan="17" height="17" valign="bottom">

<tr height="17">
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Exercise price per share</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$2.64&nbsp; -&nbsp; $20.69</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$2.64&nbsp; -&nbsp; $11.00</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$2.64&nbsp; -&nbsp; $3.65</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As discussed above, we issued 2.5 million warrants in 2005 to Arch to purchase our common stock at prices ranging from $15.69 to
$20.69.&nbsp; The warrants expire based upon certain criteria defined in the agreement but not earlier than August 1, 2006 and later than December 31, 2010, assuming we proceed with the construction and operation of a plant at their site.&nbsp; We recognized $5.8
million of general and administrative expense during the year ended December 31, 2005 related to the warrants.&nbsp; The expense was estimated using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model using an expected life of 10 months, a dividend yield of zero, expected
volatility of 56% and a risk free interest rate of 4.1%.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On June&nbsp;25, 2004, we entered into agreements to raise capital proceeds from two of our warrant holders.&nbsp; In return for 1.3
million additional warrants at an exercise price of $11.00 per share, these warrant holders agreed to exercise 3.9 million of their warrants before their contractual expiration date.&nbsp; On June&nbsp;28, 2004, we received $7.2 million of proceeds from the exercise
of 2.6 million of these warrants.&nbsp; On July 22, 2004, we received $3.4 million of proceeds from the exercise of the remaining 1.3 million warrants from the other warrant holder.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Warrant rights for 1.5 million shares of our common stock were granted to the investors in our March 2003 private equity
transactions.&nbsp; The warrants have an exercise price of $2.75 per share, are subject to adjustment, and are exercisable over a five-year period.&nbsp; The warrants were recorded at their estimated fair value of $2.4 million.&nbsp; The estimated fair value of all
of the warrants was determined using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model using an expected life of 5 years, a dividend yield of zero.&nbsp; Expected volatility of 73% and 72% and a risk free interest rate of 2.6% and 3.1% were applied to 1.2 million warrants and
349,000 warrants, respectively.&nbsp; Through the effective date of the registration statement of May 5, 2003, $2.8 million of additional expense was recognized for the increase in fair value of the warrants.&nbsp; This amount was recorded as additional paid in
capital at the effective date of registration.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In May 2003, we issued a warrant for the purchase of 1.0 million shares of our common stock at an exercise price of $2.75 per share to
a consultant as part of a three-year services agreement.&nbsp; As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 the right to purchase approximately 1.0 million, 778,000 and 472,000 of our common shares were vested under this services agreement, respectively.&nbsp; We
recognized $317,000, $950,000 and $1.3 million of expense for these services during 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively, based on the fair value of the warrants that vested during each year.&nbsp; Additionally in November 2003, we granted a warrant to this consultant
for the purchase of 100,000 shares of our common stock at an exercise price of $2.75.&nbsp; We recognized an additional $148,000 in general</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-18</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">and administrative expenses for the granting of this warrant based on the fair value of the underlying stock on the date of grant.&nbsp; We also granted a warrant to an investment banking company during the year.&nbsp; At the
date of issuance, the exercise price of the 100,000 warrant was greater than the market price of our common stock.&nbsp; Therefore, we recognized no additional expense for the issuance of this warrant.</font></p>



<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(9)&nbsp;Discontinued Pegasus Operations and Note Receivable</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On November 26, 2003, we completed an equity exchange transaction with Kennecott Energy Company.&nbsp; In accordance with terms
contained in the Equity Exchange Agreement, or the Agreement, Kennecott transferred to us its 49% membership interest in KFL and the full ownership of all related technology developed by Kennecott.&nbsp; Prior to the consummation of this transaction, we owned a 51%
membership interest in KFL.&nbsp; In exchange, we transferred our ownership interests in Pegasus Technologies Inc. to Kennecott.&nbsp; Pegasus develops and markets software that optimizes power plant operations.&nbsp; We had previously held a 65% ownership in
Pegasus.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Previously, we issued convertible debt, which was collateralized by contracts Pegasus&nbsp; executed.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 2003, the
debt was converted into KFx common stock.&nbsp; Due to the conversion of the debt, we wrote-off a debt discount of $627,000 which is reflected in interest expense in our Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2003 and paid interest of
$286,000.&nbsp; Subsequent to this conversion, we executed the exchange transaction in 2003 and divested our interest in Pegasus as described above.&nbsp; As a result of these two transactions, Pegasus became indebted to us for $2.7 million.&nbsp; The note receivable
bears interest at 7% and payments are due pursuant to an assignment of certain cash payments received by Pegasus.&nbsp; We have rights to collect payments under this note from Pegasus and to demand payment upon certain events of default. &nbsp; As of December 31,
2005 and 2004 the principal balance of this note receivable was $1.8 million and $2.1 million, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the year ended December 31, 2005, we determined that Pegasus might not have sufficient contracts to continue to meet this
obligation.&nbsp; Therefore, we have recorded an allowance for bad debt for the note receivable of $1.3 million.&nbsp; Despite this allowance, we retain all of our rights to collect payments under this note from Pegasus and to demand payment upon certain events of
default.&nbsp; The portion of the note allocated to current portion represents our best estimate of the amount we anticipate collecting in the next year.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005 the net balance due on this note was $463,000, and the current amount receivable
was $231,000.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Also part of the exchange transaction, an intercompany working capital loan from KFx to Pegasus with an outstanding balance of $9.4
million was exchanged for a contingent earn-out agreement of up to $9.4 million in the aggregate, plus accrued interest (prime rate plus 500 basis points), payable out of a portion of future cash flows generated by Pegasus.&nbsp; Due to the contingent nature of this
potential stream of future cash flows, we have not recognized an asset or any associated income.&nbsp; Through December 31, 2005, we have not received any payments pursuant to the earn-out agreement.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following table presents the summarized results of Pegasus&rsquo; discontinued operations for the Consolidated Statement of
Operations for the period from January 1, 2003 through November 26, 2003 (date of exchange transaction).</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Year Ended December 31,2005</font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2005, we repaid a $170,000 unsecured promissory note, plus accrued interest of $25,000.&nbsp; The note bore interest at 7% and
was due upon demand.&nbsp; We acquired $199,000 of non-cash property and equipment additions through capital lease obligations and a non-cash tenant improvement allowance in the amount of $283,000.</font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Year Ended December 31,2004</font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2004, we incurred a note payable obligation of $52,000 on the purchase of a vehicle.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Year Ended December 31,2003</font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On July 1, 2003, Landrica returned 450,000 shares of common stock and 1,300,000 warrants to purchase our common stock.&nbsp; There was
no cash consideration paid by us to Landrica in connection with this transaction.&nbsp; We reduced Common Stock and increased Additional Paid in Capital by the par value of these shares returned or $450.&nbsp; The warrants had not been exercised and were cancelled
upon return.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This table does not include accounts payable, accrued expenses nor asset retirement obligation, which are reported in our
December&nbsp;31, 2005 Consolidated Balance Sheets.&nbsp; We have not included any obligation in which either party has the right to terminate.&nbsp; Additionally, we have not included royalty payments, as we cannot presently determine when such payments will be made
as such payments are based upon our receipt of cash for licensing and royalties.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are obligated under non-cancelable operating leases with initial terms exceeding one year relating to office space and certain
equipment and vehicle leases.&nbsp; Rent expense in the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was $242,000, $223,000 and $255,000, respectively.&nbsp; Through September 30, 2004 certain of the leased property, principally office space was sublet to third
parties under a non-cancelable operating sublease.&nbsp; Such sub-</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-20</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">lease agreement expired on September 30, 2004.&nbsp; Sublease income was $124,000 and $143,000 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Purchase commitments related to our 750,000-tons per year plant relate to outstanding, non-cancelable purchase orders, primarily for
the fabrication of the process modules.&nbsp; Contractual commitments include agreements with consultants to advise us on proposed legislation and regulations and advocate our interests before the U.S. Congress and regulatory agencies.&nbsp; In addition a take or pay
obligation relating to a feedstock supply agreement.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Litigation</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Except as provided below, we are not engaged in any material legal proceedings to which we or any of our subsidiaries are a
party.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On April&nbsp;14, 2005, we were notified that we were named in a Demand for Arbitration by Ohio based Ultramax Corporation and its
affiliate, Decision Control Analysis Corporation (&ldquo;Ultramax&rdquo;).&nbsp; In April 2002, Ultramax granted a License Agreement (&ldquo;Agreement&rdquo;) to Pegasus Technologies, Ltd. (&ldquo;Pegasus&rdquo;) in which we owned a majority interest at the time, for
certain software which was to be used for the optimization of industrial and other processes, including processes used in the electric power generation industry.&nbsp; The Agreement provided for the payment of certain minimum royalties.&nbsp; KFx executed the
Agreement along with Pegasus.&nbsp; The Agreement provided that Pegasus and KFx were both licensees and were jointly and severally liable.&nbsp; While we were not aware of this dispute until receipt of the Demand for Arbitration, Pegasus has previously refused
Ultramax&rsquo;s claims for the payment of minimum royalties on the basis that the software did not perform as promised.&nbsp; Ultramax disagrees and claims that the terms of the Agreement have been breached.&nbsp; Ultramax is claiming damages of up to $4
million.&nbsp; On May&nbsp;24, 2005, Pegasus and KFx entered into an agreement whereby Pegasus has agreed to &ldquo;indemnify and hold harmless KFx for any monetary award or other judgment received by Ultramax through the arbitration, including any attorney&rsquo;s
fees or costs awarded to Ultramax.&rdquo;&nbsp; Pegasus and KFx have retained counsel and continue to vigorously defend the arbitration, which is currently scheduled for hearing on April 3, 2006.&nbsp; At the present time, it is not possible to predict the outcome of
this arbitration.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Royalties and Other Rights</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We owe royalty payments to parties related to certain rights that support our patents and our proprietary technology, primarily related
to Mr. Edward Koppelman the inventor of the K-Fuel process.&nbsp; As described in further detail in Note 5 &ndash; Deferred Royalty Costs.</font> </p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have granted certain rights and limited licenses for the use of certain K-Fuel technology.&nbsp; The following is a summary of the
significant parties and the rights:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Pursuant to the exchange transaction with Kennecott, they received indefinite licenses for up to three plants, with certain limitations on the location of the plants, each plant having a maximum annual capacity of three
million tons per year.&nbsp; Kennecott is obligated to pay certain royalty and license fees for these three plants, if constructed.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">

</td>

</td>

capacity of 50 million tons per year or six commercial projects, subject to certain qualifications.&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-21</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(12)&nbsp;Segments</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have identified two business segments: our Licensing segment and Operating segment.&nbsp; Our results of operations are evaluated
and allocations of capital resources are based upon the operations of these segments.&nbsp; The Licensing segment represents revenue and costs related to licensing agreements.&nbsp; As the licensee is still in the process of determining the location and design of
their plant, we do not know the exact timing of the provision of certain deliverables as defined in our agreement or the timing of revenue recognition.&nbsp; The Operating segment is comprised of all other operations.&nbsp; The majority of the assets associated with
the Operating segment are those related to construction costs and equipment of the 750,000-tons per year plant, cash and our patents.&nbsp; In addition, all intercompany eliminations and transactions flow through this segment.&nbsp; Our operations are currently
conducted in the United States.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">

<td height="3" valign="bottom" bgcolor="black"></td>
<td height="3" valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Included in total assets in the Operating segment as of December 31, 2005 $71.6 million of assets associated with the construction of
our K-Fuel plant and KFx mine project.&nbsp; Segment information on a comparative basis for the years ended December 31, 2004 and 2003 is not provided as there were no similar operations related to the Licensing segment.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-22</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(</font></b>13)&nbsp;Income Taxes</h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our operations are principally domestic, with income taxable at the federal statutory rate of 34% plus applicable state rates.&nbsp;
Deferred tax assets (liabilities) were comprised of the following:</font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have recorded a valuation allowance for the full amount of our net deferred asset because, based upon an assessment of both negative
and positive evidence, it is more likely than not that we will not realize such benefits in future tax returns.&nbsp; Our tax return net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $112 million expire in various amounts beginning in 2005.&nbsp; Certain limitations
apply to the annual amount of net operating losses that can be used to offset taxable income due to certain ownership changes, as defined in Section 382 of the Internal Revenue Code.&nbsp; Pursuant to Section 382, as a result of the change in control in 2003, we
believe our annual limitation is $11.3 million on the use of our pre-2004 net operating losses of approximately $67.6 million.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our total provision for income taxes in 2005, 2004 and 2003 were different from the amount expected by applying the statutory federal
income tax rate to our net loss as reported in our statement of Operations.&nbsp; The approximate differences are as follows:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-23</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(14)&nbsp;Related Party Transactions</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have a consulting agreement with Venners &amp; Company, Ltd. for governmental affairs services, primarily for advice on proposed
legislation and regulations and to advocate our interests before the U.S. Congress and regulatory agencies.&nbsp; Venners &amp; Company, Ltd. is controlled by John P. Venners, the brother of Theodore Venners, our Chairman and CTO.&nbsp; Prior to April&nbsp;1, 2004,
the agreement provided for monthly consulting fees of $12,000, reimbursement of expenses related to our business and certain performance-based bonuses.&nbsp; Effective April&nbsp;1, 2004, we negotiated a revised agreement with Venners &amp; Company, Ltd. for the
provision of these services at a fixed cost of $18,000 per month.&nbsp; In January 2005, this amount was increase to $25,500. Either party can terminate the agreement upon written notice.&nbsp; During the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, we paid Venners
&amp; Company $346,000, $198,000 and $249,000 respectively, in cash for consulting fees and $0, $10,000 and $58,000, respectively, for reimbursement of expenses, excluding certain bonuses.&nbsp; In 2003, we also issued Mr. John Venners 10,000 shares of our common
stock for services provided.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 2004, Venners &amp; Company, Ltd. was entitled to bonus compensation as a result of the passage of legislation H.R.&nbsp; 4520
establishing certain tax credits.&nbsp; We were required to (i) make cash payments of approximately $25,000, (ii) extend the currently active consulting agreement for a period of 43 months, (iii) issue 4,800 shares of common stock for services provided, and (iv)
issue warrants for the purchase of 150,000 shares at an average exercise price of $7.35 per share with a term of three years.&nbsp; We expensed $25,000 in general and administrative expenses related to the issuance of common stock.&nbsp; Based on the Black-Scholes
option-pricing model (assuming a weighted average risk free interest rate of 2.83%, expected option life of 3 years, expected volatility of 46.6% and no dividends) we expensed $519,000 for issuing these warrants.&nbsp; In addition, we recognized $25,000 of expense
related to the issuance of common stock.&nbsp; As a result, we recognized a total of $544,000 of general and administrative expense related to this success-based fee for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In December 2004, KFL, our wholly owned subsidiary, entered into a licensing agreement with Cook Inlet Coal, an affiliate of Kanturk
Partners LLC, under which KFL agreed to license to Cook Inlet Coal its proprietary coal processing technology for use at a coal processing plant to be operated by Cook Inlet Coal.&nbsp; Kanturk Partners owns approximately a 12% interest in Cook Inlet Coal.&nbsp; Mr.
John Venners, brother of our Chairman and CTO, Mr. Theodore Venners, has an approximately 4.5% interest in Kanturk Partners.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, we are obligated to make licensing and royalty payments to a party related to Theodore Venners, our Chairman and
CTO.&nbsp; See further discussion in Note 5 &ndash; Deferred Royalty Costs and Note 11 &ndash; Commitments and Contingencies.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(15)&nbsp;Subsequent Events</font></b></h5>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></h5>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></b> <i>Buckeye Acquisition</i></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On March&nbsp;6, 2006, we entered into a stock purchase agreement with Keller Group,&nbsp;Inc. to acquire its wholly owned subsidiary
Buckeye Industrial Mining Co. Buckeye's primary business is to mine, process and sell coal to power generating facilities and industrial users.&nbsp; The total purchase price of $37.5&nbsp;million consists of our common stock valued at $2.5&nbsp;million and
$35&nbsp;million in cash.&nbsp; We expect to close in early April 2006.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The contemplated acquisition of Buckeye continues our vertical integration strategy.&nbsp; The expected benefits of the acquisition
include providing operating cash flow and acquiring an experienced mining and coal marketing and management team.&nbsp; We believe the acquisition will also add value through access to Buckeye's established markets, infrastructure, and coal reserves.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></b> <i>Follow-On Common Stock Offering</i></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On February&nbsp;8, 2006, we sold 7 million shares of common stock at a price to the public of $18.75&nbsp;per share pursuant to a
follow-on common stock offering.&nbsp; On February 27, 2006, the underwriters exercised in full their over allotment option, purchasing an additional 1.1 million shares of common stock.&nbsp; Including the over-allotment, the offering totaled 8.1 million shares of
common stock at a price of $18.75, resulting in net proceeds of approximately $144.4 million after deducting the underwriting discounts and commissions and estimated offering expenses.&nbsp; We</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-24</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">plan to use the proceeds from this offering to fund the contemplated acquisition of Buckeye, new plant facility construction costs, the purchase of a coal-fired boiler and general corporate purposes.&nbsp; If we are unable to
consummate the acquisition of Buckeye, we intend to use the proceeds to further the development of our K-Fuel plants and for any acquisitions we may identify in the future.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Memorandum of Understanding</font></i></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In January 2006, we signed a memorandum of understanding with a coal producer to access their mine site location in Louisiana to
determine the viability of a K-Fuel plant at that location.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Fourth Quarter 2005 Discussion</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We recognized non-cash compensation expense of $2.7 million related to certain restricted stock grants to employees and consultants
during the fourth quarter of 2005.&nbsp; In addition, we recognized $5.8 million related to the issuance of warrants to Arch in October 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Fourth Quarter 2004 Discussion</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We recognized a non-cash impairment charge during the fourth quarter of 2004 of $1.3 million related to certain site-specific and plant
size-specific costs incurred associated with our 750,000-tons per year plant.&nbsp; In addition, we incurred approximately $2.2 million in costs related to performance-based bonuses for the passage of legislation that was favorable to us.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">F-25</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>
</div>
</body>
</html>

</TEXT>
</DOCUMENT>

</td>

<tr height="17">
<td height="17" valign="top">

</td>

</td>
<td height="17" valign="top">
<p><font size="3" face="Times New
Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
